commitResults.messageBody:
This commit changes renamed the chatbot and also at
the same time allows the chatbot to greet its user.
Improved the skeleton structure to add feedback capabilities

I have added a fixed String array to collect task sent by user
and the ability to reprint all the lists.
Created Task Class and the ability to mark and unmark tasks

Add support for tracking three types of tasks.

ToDos: tasks without any date/time attached to it
Deadlines: tasks that need to be done before a specific date/time
Events: tasks that start at a specific date/time and ends at a specific date/time

Creating automated text UI testing using the input/output
redirection technique to semi-automate the testing of friday.

Created exceptions, try and catch block to catch some
potential errors that user might make. Updated the testcases to
test exception handling.

Set up delete and some relevant exceptions. Updated the test cases
to test the correct output.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add Saving of Task List Mechanism
commitResults.messageBody:
The current list right now is not saved and will be lost
when the chatbot is closed.

This need to be changes as we want the list to be saved for
future references.

Created file reader and file writer to read and write the stored list
into a file to store it.

So that the list is stored into the device the chatbot is operating
on and the task list can be retrieved again when needed.

commitResults.messageTitle: Change dates represented as String to Time
commitResults.messageBody:
The date and time are represented as Strings.

We have changed the date and time to be represented, as
Time object.

This is done so that we can compare and store it properly as
it is intended to be used.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add more OOP to the chatbot
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently the body of that chatbot is lumped into a
single long string of code.

Thiw will make the code cleaner,
less repetitive, and easier to expand.

More classes have been created to cater to more OOP

So that we can see and pin point pain points

All classes in the project are placed directly in the source root folder
(src/main/java) without any package structure. This makes it difficult to manage
dependencies and locate specific classes, especially as the project grows.

Without packages, the codebase becomes cluttered, hard to maintain,
and prone to naming conflicts. Grouping related classes together improves readability, organization, and encapsulation.

Move classes into appropriately named packages. For example, all task-related classes
are placed in friday.task, command-related classes in friday.command, and UI classes
in friday.ui. Update each class with a package declaration and adjust import statements accordingly.

Packages reflect logical grouping of classes by functionality, making the project modular.
This approach allows controlled access between classes, reduces dependency errors,
and aligns with Java best practices for large-scale projects.

Keeping src/main/java as the source root ensures compatibility with build tools and
testing scripts. This refactoring also prepares the code for future extension,
such as adding more commands, tasks, or storage features.

You have a local fork of the Duke repo and want to
get changes from the original upstream repository.

Your local fork may be outdated and missing commits from
the upstream repo, such as the add-gradle-support branch.

Use git fetch upstream to retrieve all updates from the
upstream remote without changing your local branches.

Fetching updates keeps your local repository aware of
upstream changes safely, so you can inspect or merge them
later without overwriting local work.

After fetching, you can merge a specific branch like
upstream/add-gradle-support into your local master to integrate the changes.

Friday bot runs through cradle and is not easily portable.

Users cannot run the program outside the development set up.

Create a runnable JAR file with shadowJar

The JAR bundles all dependencies and specifies the entry point,
making it portable and easy to run with java -jar.

Currently most methods and class headers are not added.

This may cause confusion on what each class represents and what
each method do.

Add JavaDoc to most non-trivial classes and methods.

It is done so that others who look at this code and want to improve it,
knowns what each class or method do at a glance.

Some of the variables and practices are not in line with conventions.

This is so that the code can be easily readable for others.

Changed and alter the naming of some variable and indentations.

So that it follwos the convention that is set.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add search function to the bot
commitResults.messageBody:
There is no search function present in the bot.

This needs to be change as the search function will allow the user
to search for their task more easily

Add a serach function

It is done this way to maintain OOP and functionality.

commitResults.messageTitle: Updated the previous commit due to logic issues
commitResults.messageBody:
There is some bugs regarding the find command where an empty
keyword gives you the entire list.

This is a bug, as an empty keyword should not give you any tasks.

Update the findtasks command in FridayTaskList.

The bug exist in this method.

commitResults.messageTitle: Change variable name and method name
commitResults.messageBody:
Variable and method names are not following the convention.

This needs to change to improve readability of the code.

The variables and method names are being renamed to follow
the convention.

Friday does not currently have a GUI.

Command-line interfaces are limiting, error-prone, and less intuitive for users,
making interaction cumbersome and less engaging.

Implement a graphical user interface (GUI) using JavaFX.
Add input fields, buttons, dialog boxes,
and images for both the user and the bot to enable visual interaction.

JavaFX provides a rich set of UI components, smooth animations,
and easy binding between elements, ensuring a responsive and user-friendly experience.
Auto-scrolling and structured dialogs improve readability and usability.

A GUI allows for easier future extensions, such as themes, multimedia support,
or voice input, and reduces the learning curve for new users.

The code currently lacks proper documentation, making it harder for others
to understand the purpose, functionality, and usage of classes and methods.

Without documentation, maintaining, debugging, or extending the code becomes
time-consuming and error-prone, especially for larger projects or collaborative work.

Add Javadoc comments to all classes, methods, and important fields.
Clearly describe their purpose, parameters, return values, and any exceptions thrown.

Javadoc provides standardized, easily readable documentation that can be automatically
generated into HTML pages. It improves code readability, maintainability, and facilitates collaboration.

Using Javadoc also helps with IDE features like code hints and autocomplete,
making development faster and reducing misunderstandings when the code is used by others.
